disaster because the poor are easily intimidated.
Frustration is severely traumatic for them, and
when it occurs, they withdraw, revert to older,
more protective patterns of behavior. They be¬
come inattentive, hostile. And, if they fail,
in a supportive setting, then the loss may be
irrevocable.
For the adult who has lived longer in poverty,
the problems are more complex, and only "apparent¬
ly" easier to get at. The adult has conditioned
himself, and has been conditioned by his life in
poverty. He has learned to "absorb" the ex¬
periences of failure and of being thwarted. If,
for example, the training or educational programs
we suggest relate to something which he has ex¬
perienced, then the chances of "reaching" him
can be described in two ways: If his own ex¬
periences in that particular area were good, not
damaging, then it is reasonably certain that we
can "reach" him and that he may succeed. If, on
the other hand, he identifies what we have to
offer with an unsuccessful, unhappy, damaging
experience, then we may not "reach" him at all,
